questions.text: Two people had a fight in the morning. Later that evening, one of them was found dead. The clothes of the other person had some blood stains, and after testing, it was found that the blood belonged to the person who died. This is what type of evidence?

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of blood on accused is indirect evidence, and the fact that it matches with victim is direct evidence

questions.text: In a case of death due to alleged poisoning, the prosecution presents a toxicology expert who testifies that the victim’s body had toxic substance based on the analysis of the stomach contents. The defence argues that the expert’s testimony should be inadmissible as toxicology expert neither examined the victim while he was alive, nor he conducted the autopsy himself. Which of the below is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The toxicology expert’s testimony is inadmissible because they did not have first-hand knowledge of the victim’s condition at the time of death.

options.label: B
options.text: The toxicology testimony is admissible as it is based on expert opinion, not on first-hand knowledge.

options.label: C
options.text: The forensic expert’s testimony is admissible only if it can be corroborated by a common witness who had first-hand knowledge of the victim’s condition.

questions.correct_answer: B. The toxicology testimony is admissible as it is based on expert opinion, not on first-hand knowledge.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the witness in the court?

options.label: A
options.text: Expert witnesses can testify about something even if they did not personally observe it, as long as it is accepted in their field of expertise.

options.label: B
options.text: Expert witnesses must never testify about anything they did not personally witness or participate in.

options.label: C
options.text: Expert witness cannot be considered hostile witness

options.label: D
options.text: Expert witnesses are required to have prior experience testifying in court to be considered qualified.

questions.correct_answer: A. Expert witnesses can testify about something even if they did not personally observe it, as long as it is accepted in their field of expertise.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Expert witnesses can testify about something even if they did not personally observe it, as long as it is accepted in their field of expertise.

questions.text: In a criminal trial, the prosecution calls a witness who initially agrees to testify but then refuses to cooperate, contradicting prior statements. The prosecutor seeks permission to ask leading questions during examination-in-chief. Under what circumstance can this be allowed?

options.label: A
options.text: A leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is an expert in the subject matter of the case.

options.label: B
options.text: A leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is hostile.

options.label: C
options.text: A leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the evidence of witness fails to prove that accused has done the crime.

questions.correct_answer: B. A leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is hostile.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) A leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is hostile.

questions.text: In a mock trial as part of legal training for medical professionals, the concept of a 'hostile witness' is introduced. Dr. Lalit, a senior resident, is asked to play the role of an expert witness, and during the proceedings, a discussion arises regarding the characteristics of a hostile witness. Which of the following statements is false regarding the nature of a hostile witness in court?

options.label: A
options.text: Cannot be examined by same side lawyer

options.label: B
options.text: Court will declare a witness as hostile on suggestion of prosecution lawyer

options.label: C
options.text: A common or an expert witness can be hostile

options.label: D
options.text: Witness has some motive for concealing the truth

questions.correct_answer: A. Cannot be examined by same side lawyer
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Cannot be examined by same side lawyer

questions.text: Which of the following is true in context of Inquest in India?

options.label: A
options.text: The Executive magistrate need to be informed of all types of inquests

options.label: B
options.text: Investigating police officer can go to witness, but cannot summon them to police station

options.label: C
options.text: Doctor can refuse to do autopsy if he thinks probable cause of death is natural

options.label: D
options.text: Doctor has to handover the dead body to relatives after the postmortem

questions.correct_answer: A. The Executive magistrate need to be informed of all types of inquests
questions.explanation: Ans. A) The Executive magistrate need to be informed of all types of inquests

questions.text: Which of the following is a valid reason for conducting an in-camera trial in a rape case under Indian law?

options.label: A
options.text: To ensure that the victim's dignity is preserved during the trial.

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent the possibility of the accused being publicly humiliated during the trial

options.label: C
options.text: To provide a secure environment for the victim by not allowing accused to be present during the trial

questions.correct_answer: A. To ensure that the victim's dignity is preserved during the trial.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) To ensure that the victim's dignity is preserved during the trial.

questions.text: A patient in a persistent vegetative state without a living will is on life support. The family is divided on whether to continue life-sustaining treatment. Which category of euthanasia would be considered if the doctors decide to withdraw life support based on the family's decision?
A 7-year child is likely to have following set of permanent Molars and permanent premolars:
questions.correct_answer: B. 4 permanent molar, 0 permanent pre molars
questions.explanation: Ans. B) 4 permanent molar, 0 permanent pre molars

questions.text: Which of the following method is based on age determination based on weight and height of the erupting teeth?
First permanent teeth to erupt in socket of temporary teeth?
Why is anthropometry more useful in adults than in children?

options.label: A
options.text: Adult body proportions are more consistent and stable, while children's bodies undergo rapid changes during growth

options.label: B
options.text: It is unethical to keep measurements of children body parts owing to risk of misuse in sexual trafficking

options.label: C
options.text: Adult body structure is easier to measure compared to children

options.label: D
options.text: Children’s body measurements remain consistent and do not change with age.

questions.correct_answer: A. Adult body proportions are more consistent and stable, while children's bodies undergo rapid changes during growth
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Adult body proportions are more consistent and stable, while children's bodies undergo rapid changes during growth

questions.text: During a training session in forensic medicine, a resident learns about the importance of analyzing the vitreous humor in determining the postmortem interval. Which constituent of the vitreous humor is most helpful in accurately estimating the postmortem interval?
Which is the most important reason for preferring Letulle’s technique of autopsy in infants, particularly when congenital anomalies are suspected?

options.label: A
options.text: It involves removal of the brain first, which allows for better preservation of the cranial contents in cases of congenital abnormalities.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps to preserve relationship between the organs as they are found in situ, making it easier to identify anomalies in malformations without disturbing anatomical arrangement.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows opening the chest and abdominal cavities in sequence, which helps to better identify congenital anomalies, as compared to Ghon's, Virchow's, or Rokitansky's.

options.label: D
options.text: It involves the dissection of the spinal cord first, which is particularly useful for infants with congenital malformations.

questions.correct_answer: B. It helps to preserve relationship between the organs as they are found in situ, making it easier to identify anomalies in malformations without disturbing anatomical arrangement.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) It helps to preserve relationship between the organs as they are found in situ, making it easier to identify anomalies in malformations without disturbing anatomical arrangement.

questions.text: Which of the following sources is least relevant in conducting a psychological autopsy?

options.label: D
options.text: Analysis of personal diaries and electronic communications

questions.correct_answer: B. Toxicology analysis of the body
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Toxicology analysis of the body

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the effect of environmental temperature on rigor mortis is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: In hot environments, rigor mortis sets in slowly because the body’s metabolic processes are slowed down.

options.label: B
options.text: In cold environments, rigor mortis sets in slowly because the body’s metabolic processes are slowed down

options.label: C
options.text: In cold environments, rigor mortis persist for more time due to faster decomposition

options.label: D
options.text: In hot environments, rigor mortis persist for more time due to faster decomposition

questions.correct_answer: B. In cold environments, rigor mortis sets in slowly because the body’s metabolic processes are slowed down
questions.explanation: Ans. B) In cold environments, rigor mortis sets in slowly because the body’s metabolic processes are slowed down

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the muscular changes that occur after death.

options.label: A
options.text: Rigor mortis typically begins 1–2 hours after death.

options.label: D
options.text: Rigor mortis affects both voluntary and involuntary muscles.

questions.correct_answer: B. Cadaveric spasm affects involuntary muscles.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Cadaveric spasm affects involuntary muscles.

questions.text: A forensic expert needs to visualize lipid accumulation in a tissue sample. Which staining technique should be utilized to specifically stain fats?
Penetrating neck trauma:

options.label: A
options.text: Violating the platysma layer of the neck

options.label: C
options.text: Any trauma damaging vital structure in neck

questions.correct_answer: A. Violating the platysma layer of the neck
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Violating the platysma layer of the neck

questions.text: A person is found dead in his home. He was living alone. Neighbours called the police when they experienced a foul smell from home. On autopsy, injuries were seen as shown below. Based on above context which statement is true?
Which of the following is true with respect to bomb blast injuries?

options.label: A
options.text: Marshal’s triad occurs in secondary blast injuries and consists of multiple small abrasions, bruises and fractures

options.label: B
options.text: Primary blast injuries occur due to high velocity wind and causes injuries to gas filled internal organs like ear, lungs and intestines

options.label: C
options.text: Primary blast injuries occur due to high pressure shock wave and does not cause external injuries

options.label: D
options.text: Victim can be thrown away in tertiary blast injuries due to high pressure shock wave

questions.correct_answer: C. Primary blast injuries occur due to high pressure shock wave and does not cause external injuries
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Primary blast injuries occur due to high pressure shock wave and does not cause external injuries

questions.text: Match the following types of firearm injuries with their characteristic features. Types of Wounds: Contact wound Close-range wound Distant-range wound Exit wound Features: Tattooing (stippling) present, but no muzzle imprint Irregular, everted margins, usually larger than entry Circular entry, inverted margin, grease collar, no tattooing Muzzle imprint and blackening inside wound Which of the following is the correct match?

A 73-year-old man is found dead in his apartment. Autopsy reveals multiple neck bruises and abrasions as well as the finding shown in the image. Assuming that the death results from an asphyxia mechanism, what is the most likely manner of death?

An adult male of about 40 year old age was found dead on the floor in his room, in prone position. A Tiffin box with orange, rice along with half liquor bottle was also found beside him. No disturbance of any kind i.e. clothing, bedding, almirah or any articles was noticed on the spot by police. On Autopsy, the finding as shown in image below was seen. What is the likely manner of death?

35-year male, was found hanging in his bedroom, as shown below. A horizontal ligature mark below the thyroid cartilage, reddish with ecchymotic edges, was observed. Dissection revealed ecchymosis in the subcutaneous tissues, neck muscle trauma, and fractured trachea. Multiple abrasions and contusions on the chin, arms, and abdomen were seen. Likely cause and manner of death:

A body is recovered from a freshwater canal. During autopsy, the lungs appear ballooned, waterlogged, and show soft, pale-pinkish patches over their surface, each measuring about 1–2 cm in diameter. These lesions are believed to result from rupture of alveolar walls due to increased intrathoracic pressure during forceful inhalation of water. Which of the following findings is most likely being described?
Identify the gestational age of the fetus if the Crown Rump Length is 16 cm, scalp hair has appeared, but testes not yet appeared:
The Spalding sign, characterized by the overlapping of cranial bones in a fetus after intrauterine death, is primarily caused by:

options.label: A
options.text: Severe maternal hypertension leading to intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)

options.label: B
options.text: Brain ischemia leading to intrauterine death

options.label: C
options.text: Shrinkage of the cerebrum after death, leading to loss of alignment and overriding of cranial bones

options.label: D
options.text: A genetic anomaly causing cranial bone malformation

questions.correct_answer: C. Shrinkage of the cerebrum after death, leading to loss of alignment and overriding of cranial bones

questions.text: An 18-month-old female baby was referred for recurrent hypoglycemic attacks. Her first hypoglycemic attack occurred when she was 13 months old when her mother, who is a hospital nurse, noticed lethargy, prolonged sleep and irritability. She was brough to hospital where blood sugar level was of 30 mg/dl. Since then such attacks have occurred 5 times, and she has been successfully managed with high dextrose (D25%), octreotide and glucagon. During all attacks, her blood glucose is found to be low (about 20-40 mg/dl), and high insulin (3500-4000 pmol/L). During this hospital admission, one physician noticed needle marks on her both deltoids. The physician ordered C-peptide levels which was found to be almost negligible. Likely Diagnosis:
questions.correct_answer: A. Exogenous insulin administration to baby
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Exogenous insulin administration to baby

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant, Sarah, is found deceased in her crib one morning. The parents report that Sarah had been healthy, was placed to sleep. There were no apparent signs of distress or illness before her death. During the autopsy, the forensic pathologist observes no signs of external trauma, infection, or congenital abnormalities. Toxicology tests come back negative for drugs or toxins. The pathologist concludes that the cause of death is consistent with Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS). Which is likely manner of death?
What is the most likely cause of paradoxical undressing in individuals who die from hypothermia?

options.label: A
options.text: Sudden vasodilation in the extremities causes a false sensation of warmth, leading to the removal of clothing.

options.label: B
options.text: The brain's temperature regulation center becomes impaired, causing the person to misinterpret the environment and undress.

options.label: C
options.text: Increased shivering causes discomfort, prompting the person to remove clothing to cool down.

options.label: D
options.text: A reduction in blood flow to the muscles causes extreme fatigue, leading to an involuntary removal of clothing.

questions.correct_answer: B. The brain's temperature regulation center becomes impaired, causing the person to misinterpret the environment and undress.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) The brain's temperature regulation center becomes impaired, causing the person to misinterpret the environment and undress.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for frostbite?

options.label: A
options.text: Quick Rewarming the affected area with hot water

options.label: B
options.text: Massaging the frozen tissue to improve blood flow

options.label: C
options.text: Gradually rewarming the affected area with warm (not hot) water

options.label: D
options.text: Using ice packs to prevent further tissue damage

questions.correct_answer: C. Gradually rewarming the affected area with warm (not hot) water
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Gradually rewarming the affected area with warm (not hot) water

questions.text: True about the below image:

options.label: A
options.text: Heat stiffening due to ATP depletion

options.label: B
options.text: Protein coagulation due to heat stroke

options.label: C
options.text: Can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem burns

questions.correct_answer: C. Can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem burns
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem burns

questions.text: A 42-year-old male construction worker is brought to the emergency department after collapsing at a worksite on a particularly hot afternoon. He appeared confused and irritable. His rectal temperature was recorded as 41.2°C (106.2°F). He is found to have rapid, shallow breathing. His pulse is 140 beats per minute, blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 30 breaths per minute. Which of the following is Likely in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Patient is aware that he has a high body temperature.

questions.text: A mother delivers twins, but one baby has much larger development as compared to other. On DNA testing, only one of the twins matches the husband. What could be the cause?

A 28-year-old man is found unresponsive in his apartment with multiple bloodstains on his clothing. The first responders to the scene need to determine whether the bloodstains are recent or if some might have been present for a longer period. Which method should the forensic team use to confirm the presence of blood in both the recent and older stains on the clothing?
According to which rule, a person is not punished if the unlawful act is the product of a mental disease or defect?
Which of the following would not typically occur during the lucid interval in an epidural hematoma?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient regains full consciousness and appears normal

options.label: B
options.text: The patient may experience confusion and disorientation

options.label: C
options.text: The patient’s neurological status improves temporarily

options.label: D
options.text: The hematoma is small and not yet causing significant pressure

questions.correct_answer: B. The patient may experience confusion and disorientation

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with agitation, dilated pupils, and tachycardia. He appears restless and paranoid, and he is sweating profusely. His blood pressure is elevated. What is the likely cause of these symptoms?
Which of the following is the primary mechanism by which fomepizole prevents the toxic effects of ethylene glycol poisoning?

options.label: A
options.text: Fomepizole inhibits the enzyme responsible for converting glycolic acid to oxalic acid, directly preventing renal toxicity.

options.label: B
options.text: Fomepizole Non competitively inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH), preventing the formation of toxic metabolites like glycolic acid and oxalic acid.

options.label: C
options.text: Fomepizole has Higher affinity for alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH)

questions.correct_answer: C. Fomepizole has Higher affinity for alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Fomepizole has Higher affinity for alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH)

questions.text: A 24-year-old male present to hospital with consumption of an unknown substance. His respiratory rate is 24 / min, Pulse 110 / min, BP 160/100, and had 2 episodes of seizures. What is the most likely poison?
In a case involving suspected chemical exposure, an autopsy reveals extensive skin discoloration as seen in the image. What can be the likely mechanism?

options.label: A
options.text: Reaction of nitric acid with amino acids in the skin

options.label: B
options.text: Deep tissue liquefactive necrosis by nitric acid.

options.label: C
options.text: Deep tissue liquefactive necrosis by some alkali.

questions.correct_answer: A. Reaction of nitric acid with amino acids in the skin
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Reaction of nitric acid with amino acids in the skin

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to hospital with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea after accidentally ingesting seeds that resemble those shown in the image. Which toxin is responsible for his symptoms, and what is its mechanism of action?

options.label: A
options.text: Abrin, an RNA N-glycosidase that inhibits protein synthesis.

options.label: B
options.text: Ricin, a DNA polymerase inhibitor that disrupts cellular replication.

options.label: C
options.text: Cyanide, inhibits cytochrome c oxidase in the electron transport chain.

options.label: D
options.text: Solanine, disrupts acetylcholinesterase leading to cholinergic excess.

questions.correct_answer: A. Abrin, an RNA N-glycosidase that inhibits protein synthesis.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Abrin, an RNA N-glycosidase that inhibits protein synthesis.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman with a history of opioid abuse is admitted to a rehabilitation center. She reports experiencing excessive yawning, muscle aches, anxiety, sweating, and nausea whenever she attempts to quit heroin. Which of the following best describes the expected pupillary finding in this patient?

A 40-year-old male from a rural community in Central India presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of progressive stiffness and spasticity in his lower limbs. He reports no loss of sensation, changes in cognition, or bladder dysfunction. Dietary history reveals a significant consumption of a local legume, as a staple. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which site is considered the best for collecting blood samples for toxicology analysis during an autopsy?
In cyanide poisoning, the characteristic cherry red discoloration of the skin is best explained by:

options.label: A
options.text: Accumulation of oxygenated hemoglobin as cells are not able to use oxygen

options.label: B
options.text: Increased carboxyhemoglobin due to carbon monoxide production.

options.label: C
options.text: Cyanide binding to hemoglobin, enhancing oxygen affinity.

options.label: D
options.text: Formation of a cyanide-cytochrome c oxidase complex with a cherry red color.

questions.correct_answer: A. Accumulation of oxygenated hemoglobin as cells are not able to use oxygen
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Accumulation of oxygenated hemoglobin as cells are not able to use oxygen.

questions.text: A medical examiner is called to a crime scene where a body has been found. The examiner notices a distinctive smell of burnt rope at the scene. Based on this clue, what is the most likely cause of the poisoning?

Identify which of the following statements are true regarding the materials required for forensic analysis of specific poisons: Vitreous humor is commonly examined for alcohol poisoning. The skin is analyzed for decomposition in cases of strychnine poisoning. Brain tissue is essential for detecting organophosphate poisoning. Fatty tissue is primarily used for examining pesticides and insecticides.
What is the best preservative for preserving bone for toxicology analysis after postmortem?
